"SECTION 1. FINDINGS." Congress finds that the centennial of World War I, from 2014 to 2018, marks a significant period in history. The war saw the United States supporting allies for the first time in defense of liberty, leading to American soldiers fighting abroad. Despite being called "the war to end all wars", the US would later commit troops to foreign lands three more times in the 20th century. Over 4,000,000 Americans served in uniform during World War I. During World War I, 2 future presidents, Harry S. Truman and Dwight D. Eisenhower, served in uniform. 2 million Americans served overseas, including 200,000 naval personnel. The US suffered 375,000 casualties, with 116,516 deaths. The events of 1914-1918 had a profound impact on the world and the US. The centennial of WWI allows Americans to learn and honor the sacrifices of their predecessors through commemorative programs and activities. The United States lacks a national memorial for World War I, unlike other major conflicts of the 20th century. In 1921, Kansas City dedicated a site for a memorial attended by military leaders from various countries. In 1924, the cornerstone of the 217-foot Liberty Memorial Tower was laid in Italy. President Calvin Coolidge delivered the keynote address at the Memorial's dedication ceremony in 1926. The Memorial and surrounding grounds were completed in 1938, with an inscription honoring those who served in World War I. The Liberty Memorial is recognized as a national symbol of World War I by the 106th Congress. The museum at the base of the Memorial is designated as "America's National World War I Museum" by the 108th Congress. The District of Columbia War Memorial was authorized in 1924 by the 68th Congress. The DC War Memorial, dedicated in 1931 by President Herbert Hoover, honors the 499 residents of the District of Columbia who died in World War I. It is located on the national Mall in Washington, adjacent to other war memorials. Unlike the others, it is not a national memorial. The Act establishes a commission in Kansas City, Missouri to oversee the centennial observance of World War I and rename the Liberty Memorial and DC War Memorial as the "National World War I Museum and Memorial" and the "District of Columbia and National World War I Memorial" respectively. The Act defines key terms such as "America's National World War I Museum," "Commission," and "veterans service organization." It also establishes the World War I Centennial Commission. The World War I Centennial Commission is established with 24 members appointed by various leaders and the President to represent the people of the United States, including veterans and members of the Armed Forces. The World War I Centennial Commission is established with 24 members appointed by various leaders and the President to represent the people of the United States, including veterans and members of the Armed Forces. Members are appointed for life, vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and the initial meeting must occur within 30 days of all members being appointed. The World War I Centennial Commission, consisting of 24 members appointed by various leaders and the President, must hold its first meeting once all members are appointed. Meetings will be held at the America's National World War I Museum, with the Chair calling meetings at least once a year. Thirteen members constitute a quorum for meetings. The World War I Centennial Commission must hold meetings with 13 members constituting a quorum. The Commission will select a Chair and Vice Chair from its members. SEC. 5. DUTIES. The Commission's duties include planning, developing, and executing programs to commemorate the centennial of World War I, encouraging participation from private organizations and governments, coordinating activities nationwide, serving as an information hub, and making recommendations to Congress and the President. Periodic reports are required. The Commission is required to submit periodic reports to Congress and the President on its activities and plans, as well as specific recommendations for commemorating the centennial of World War I. The Commission is granted powers to submit reports to Congress and the President on its activities and plans, along with recommendations for commemorating the centennial of World War I. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and receive administrative support services as needed. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission under this Act. The Commission is authorized to procure supplies, services, and property through contracts, leases, or legal agreements, with a limitation on agreements extending beyond the Commission's termination date. They can use postal services and accept gifts, bequests, and devises. The Commission is authorized to accept gifts, bequests, and devises of services or property to aid its work. Money and proceeds from sales received shall be deposited in the Treasury and available for disbursement upon the Commission's order. Commission personnel matters are addressed in Section 7. Members of the Commission serve without compensation. They are allowed travel expenses and the Chair appoints an executive director and necessary personnel, with the authority to set their compensation. The Chair of the Commission cannot set compensation for the executive director or personnel above a certain level. The executive director and staff may work at the America's National World War I Museum if space is provided. Federal departments can detail employees to the Commission upon request. The Chair of the Commission can detail employees from Federal departments to assist in carrying out duties under this Act. The Chair may also procure temporary and intermittent services as needed. SEC. 8. TERMINATION OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission will end 30 days after completing activities for the centennial observation of World War I or on July 28, 2019. The Federal Advisory Committee Act applies to the Commission's activities, with an exception. SEC. 9. DESIGNATION OF NATIONAL WORLD WAR I MEMORIALS. The Liberty Memorial in Kansas City, Missouri is designated as the National World War I Museum and Memorial. The District of Columbia War Memorial in Washington, DC is designated as the District of Columbia and National World War I Memorial. The Commission may plan and execute ceremonies for these designations. The World War I Memorial Foundation has the authority to establish a commemorative work at the site of the District of Columbia and National World War I Memorial. The work must complement and preserve the existing memorial. Compliance with standards for commemorative works and the location of the memorial are also important considerations. The rededication of the District of Columbia and National World War I Memorial is authorized by Congress, following specific guidelines outlined in chapter 89 of title 40, United States Code. The provisions regarding site approval and location of commemorative works do not apply to this Act. Excess funds from the project will be deposited accordingly. The World War I Memorial Foundation will deposit any excess funds with the Secretary of the Treasury for the memorial's maintenance or commemorative work authorized by Congress. SEC. 10. EFFECTIVE DATE: This Act will take effect 90 days after its enactment.
